section.title: Simple Interest
section.p: Interest can accumulate as simple interest, which means that the accumulation function is linear. If we have an annual simple interest rate of \iota, then our accumulation factor is a(t) = 1 + \iota t and therefore our accumulation function is A(t) = A(0)(1+\iota t).

This does not have to be annual. We would like the period for \iota and the units for time t to match, although we will see that because of linearity, this is not quite as necessary as it is with compound interest.

introduction.p: We begin with some exercises involving simple interest.

task.p: A deposit of 14000 in an account with 4.5% annual simple interest. Find the value 18 months after the deposit.
Find the present value of 19500 at time t = 31 where t is in months, using an annual simple interest rate of 2.75%.

A deposit of 1200 is made into an account bearing a 3% effective annual interest rate. Find the value after 2 years and 17 days, where interest over a portion of a year is accumulated at a 3% annual simple interest rate.
After 143 days, a deposit of 1200 is worth 1228.20. Find the annual simple interest rate.
A deposit of 2112 in an account with an annual simple interest rate of 4.5% has grown to 2145.85 after t days. Find t.

introduction.p: Let's consider the mathematical benefits of linearity. Suppose $1000 is invested in an account with a 12% annual simple interest rate.

task.p: What is the balance in the account after 1 month? Comparing that balance to the original investment of 1000, what is the monthly simple interest rate?
What is the balance in the account after 3 months? Comparing that balance to the original investment of 1000, what is the quarterly simple interest rate?
What is the balance in the account after 6 months? Comparing that balance to the original investment of 1000, what is the semiannual simple interest rate?
What is the two-month simple interest rate?
What do you notice? What role does linearity play? What is a mathematical benefit of linearity?

introduction.p: Simple interest is often used to value accounts between interest compounding periods. For example, if interest compounded monthly, and we wanted to value after 3 months and 12 days, we would value using the effective monthly compound rate for the 3 months, and use a simple interest approximation for the 12 days.

task.p: This problem is modified from . Suppose an account has an effective annual interest rate of 12%. Simple interest (also at 12%) is applied to fractions of a year. Calculate the number of years (including fractions) it will take for an investment of 1000 to accumulate to 3000.
Why might we use simple interest as an approximation for fractions of an interest period?

statement.p: Try to solve the following in two different ways, and explain what is going on. This illustrates the limitations of linearity.

A deposit of 7800 is made on day 39 of a year, and another deposit of 5150 is made on day 57 of the same year. The account has an annual simple interest rate of 4%. Find the account balance half-way through the year (assume a 360-day year).
FM Exam problems often mix compound interest and simple interest. Solve the following, which is from a former exam:

Joe deposits 10 today and another 30 in five years into a fund paying simple interest of 11% per year. Tina will make the same deposits, but the 10 will be deposited n years from today and the 30 will be deposited 2n years from today. Tina's deposits earn an effective annual rate of 9.15%. At the end of 10 years, the accumulated amount of Tina's deposits equals the accumulated amount of Joe's deposits. Calculate n.

Two interest rate structures are equivalent if they yield the same values at all of the same times. Why would a simple interest rate structure never be equivalent to a compound interest rate structure? Illustrate with an example.
What is simple and what is not so simple about simple interest?
